abstract.p: August Wilson's Jitney, which has won Drama Critics Circle best American play Award, started out at Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick, NJ; other New Jersey theatrical firsts include David Auburn's Proof at George Street Playhouse, New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's production of Enter the Guardsman and Amos Kamil's The Flame Keeper; photo (S)

block.p: New Jersey saw it first. That's the perennial claim of the state's theatergoers, even now that the New York season is over.
Although August Wilson's ''Jitney'' opened Off Broadway on April 25, missing the deadline for other prizes, it came in just in time to win the Drama Critics Circle best American play Award.
New Jersey saw it first. That's the perennial claim of the state's theatergoers, even now that the New York season is over.
Although August Wilson's ''Jitney'' opened Off Broadway on April 25, missing the deadline for other prizes, it came in just in time to win the Drama Critics Circle best American play Award.

But the unearthing of the work through which Mr. Wilson (right) admittedly found his playwriting voice, was a coup for Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick. First in his cycle of prize winners about black American life, ''Jitney'' was produced in Pittsburgh in 1982, but it did not travel until Crossroads paved the way in 1997. Now it is a New York hit.

To the list of New Jersey firsts, add ''Proof,'' which opens at the Manhattan Theater Club on Tuesday. Audiences at the New Play Series at George Street Playhouse, next-door neighbor to Crossroads, were introduced to David Auburn's mystery play last May.

Then the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival made a big noise in Madison, with a new chamber musical, ''Enter the Guardsman.'' The star who brought in much of the noise was Robert Cuccioli. The show opens today at the Dimson Theater Off-Broadway, with Mr. Cuccioli, and Mark Jacoby, also repeating his New Jersey leading role.

''The Flame Keeper,'' Amos Kamil's post-Holocaust play, is to arrive at the 47th Street Theater on June 20, after waiting for a theater all season. Where did it turn up first? Luna Stage in Montclair in 1998.
